item.title: Get ready for weather whiplash in Southern California this fall and winter
item.description: Scientists say La Niña is likely, but that doesn’t necessarily mean a dry winter in Southern California.
item.source:markdown: Scientists say La Niña is likely, but that doesn’t necessarily mean a dry winter in Southern California.

item.title: Long Beach extends ‘smart’ public restrooms at parks and pier
item.description: Each ADA-accessible unit includes touchless toilets, faucets and soap dispensers, as well as more than 20 sensors to detect motion, water and waste levels.
item.source:markdown: Each ADA-accessible unit includes touchless toilets, faucets and soap dispensers, as well as more than 20 sensors to detect motion, water and waste levels.

item.title: LA councilmember Curren Price hospitalized
item.description: His office says Price was suffering from dehydration at a groundbreaking for the L.A. Convention Center expansion project.
item.source:markdown: His office says Price was suffering from dehydration at a groundbreaking for the L.A. Convention Center expansion project.

item.title: Hundreds of celebrities relaunch a McCarthy-era committee to defend free speech
item.description: The Committee for the First Amendment first launched in the 1940s, when the House Un-American Activities Committee accused Hollywood actors, directors and writers of being communists or sympathizers.
item.source:markdown: The Committee for the First Amendment first launched in the 1940s, when the House Un-American Activities Committee accused Hollywood actors, directors and writers of being communists or sympathizers.

item.title: LA council members bypass strict labor standards for most fast-tracked affordable housing projects
item.description: Only high-rise developments would be required to hire union construction workers under plan advanced in committee this week.
item.source:markdown: Only high-rise developments would be required to hire union construction workers under plan advanced in committee this week.

item.title: When will the government reopen? Here's how long past shutdowns lasted
item.description: Government shutdowns lasting more than a few days were relatively rare — until recently. The 2018-19 shutdown was the longest in U.S. history, stretching on for five weeks.
item.source:markdown: Government shutdowns lasting more than a few days were relatively rare — until recently. The 2018-19 shutdown was the longest in U.S. history, stretching on for five weeks.

item.title: Where things stand with Trump's National Guard deployments
item.description: The Trump administration has deployed or threatened to deploy National Guard troops in more than half a dozen American cities that it says are crime ridden.
item.source:markdown: The Trump administration has deployed or threatened to deploy National Guard troops in more than half a dozen American cities that it says are crime ridden.

item.title: ‘Going to be chaos’: advocates alarmed by last-minute national parks shutdown plans
item.description: Many park sites remain open without full regular staffing.
item.source:markdown: Many park sites remain open without full regular staffing.

item.title: Jane Goodall, legendary primatologist, has died at age 91
item.description: Jane Goodall, primatologist who transformed our understanding of the lives of apes, has died, according to an announcement from the Jane Goodall Institute.
item.source:markdown: Jane Goodall, primatologist who transformed our understanding of the lives of apes, has died, according to an announcement from the Jane Goodall Institute.

item.title: The LAX Automated People Mover is long delayed and $880M over budget. Here's what went wrong
item.description: According to a grand jury report the contractor took advantage of strained relations and political pressures to “force” the city to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to settle disputes.
item.source:markdown: According to a grand jury report the contractor took advantage of strained relations and political pressures to “force” the city to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to settle disputes.

item.title: Poll: Agreement that political violence may be necessary to right the country grows
item.description: On hot button issues, a majority say children should be vaccinated; controlling gun violence is more important than gun rights; and Epstein files should be released, in a new NPR/PBS News/Marist poll.
item.source:markdown: On hot button issues, a majority say children should be vaccinated; controlling gun violence is more important than gun rights; and Epstein files should be released, in a new NPR/PBS News/Marist poll.

item.title: Dozens killed in a powerful earthquake that hit the Philippines
item.description: The death toll was expected to rise from the Tuesday magnitude-6.9 earthquake that trapped an unspecified number of residents in the hard-hit city of Bogo and outlying rural towns in Cebu province.
item.source:markdown: The death toll was expected to rise from the Tuesday magnitude-6.9 earthquake that trapped an unspecified number of residents in the hard-hit city of Bogo and outlying rural towns in Cebu province.

item.title: Trump administration uses taxpayer dollars to blame Democrats for government shutdown
item.description: Federal employees across the government reported seeing similar messages. Experts say the messages may violate ethics laws meant to keep partisan politics out of day-to-day governing.
item.source:markdown: Federal employees across the government reported seeing similar messages. Experts say the messages may violate ethics laws meant to keep partisan politics out of day-to-day governing.

item.title: Financial aid applications open today, with state-based options for undocumented students

item.source:markdown: Federal and state-based aid can help students pay for tuition and fees, as well as other essentials, offering some an opportunity for a debt-free education.

item.title: Many services grind to a halt as federal government shuts down
item.description: Much of the federal government is now shut down after Republicans and Democrats in the Senate failed to agree on a funding plan to keep the government open.
item.source:markdown: Much of the federal government is now shut down after Republicans and Democrats in the Senate failed to agree on a funding plan to keep the government open.

item.title: Beach access remains difficult for people with wheelchairs. Here are some resources to help
item.description: Improvements in recent years include beach mats and specially adapted public wheelchairs. But advocates say access still falls short.
item.source:markdown: Improvements in recent years include beach mats and specially adapted public wheelchairs. But advocates say access still falls short.

item.title: LA County leaders, frustrated with report on January fire response, vote to take action

UCLA reclaims hundreds of research grants that Trump cut off over alleged antisemitism

item.title: Is Taiwan Prepared for an Attack by China?
item.description: Is Taiwan prepared for a blockade, missile strikes, or even an invasion by China? The answer goes beyond military strength—civilian resilience is a crucial part of Taiwan’s national security. RAND’s Marta Kepe and Scott Harold break down the strengths and weaknesses of Taiwan’s civilian resilience efforts, highlighting the public’s role in preparing for and defending against aggression by China.
item.source:markdown: Is Taiwan prepared for a blockade, missile strikes, or even an invasion by China? The answer goes beyond military strength—civilian resilienceis a crucial part of Taiwan’s national security. RAND’s MartaKepeand Scott Harold break down the strengths andweaknesses of Taiwan’s civilian resilienceefforts,highlightingthe public’s role in preparing for and defending against aggressionby China.

item.title: Medicaid Unwinding Associated with Less Medication Treatment for Opioid Use Disorder
item.description: The end of pandemic-era enrollment enhancements for Medicaid was associated with a rise in the number of people ending medication treatment for opioid use disorder, as well as a decrease in the number of people beginning such treatment.
item.source:markdown: The end of pandemic-era enrollment enhancements for Medicaid was associated with a rise in the number of people ending medication treatment for opioid use disorder, as well as a decrease in the number of people beginning such treatment.

item.title: Best things to do in LA and SoCal: Sept. 29 - Oct. 2
item.description: Sparks fly at the Greek, Twilight in Concert, a reading group (with cats!), a new Corita Kent exhibit at Marciano Art Foundation, Kamala Harris at the Wiltern and more of the best things to do this week.

item.title: Vandenberg Family Child Care Program Announces Participation in the Child and Adult Care Food Program
item.description: Vandenberg SFB's Family Child Care program is proud to announce its participation in the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Child and Adult Care Food Program (CACFP). The CACFP is available without charge to all enrolled children in the FCC program.  This will allow the FCC Providers to receive reimbursement for meals provided to children within their care.
item.source:markdown: Vandenberg SFB's Family Child Care program is proud to announce its participation in the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Child and Adult Care Food Program (CACFP). The CACFP is available without charge to all enrolled children in the FCC program. This will allow the FCC Providers to receive reimbursement for meals provided to children within their care.

item.title: Vandenberg Military Working Dog Dani A248 Retires From Service
item.description: U.S. Air Force Dani A248, 30th Security Forces Squadron military working dog, retires from service at Vandenberg Space Force Base, Calif., Sept. 26, 2025. Dani was adopted by Tiffany Core, one of Dani's former dog handlers. The event commemorated Dani's seven years of service in the U.S. Air Force. Over his career he supported 17 United States Secret Service missions supporting the President and Vice President of the United States, Joint Chief of Staff and Foreign Dignitaries.
item.source:markdown:
U.S. Air Force Dani A248, 30th Security Forces Squadron military working dog, retires from service at Vandenberg Space Force Base, Calif., Sept. 26, 2025. Dani was adopted by Tiffany Core, one of Dani's former dog handlers. The event commemorated Dani's seven years of service in the U.S. Air Force. Over his career he supported 17 United States Secret Service missions supporting the President and Vice President of the United States, Joint Chief of Staff and Foreign Dignitaries.
![Two people stand behind a dog for a portrait photo outside. They smile for the camera.](https://media.defense.gov/2025/Sep/29/2003811848/300/300/0/250926-X-DW038-1006.JPG)

item.title: GoBiz, REACH leaders tour VSFB after 'Space Vandenberg' initiative announcement
item.description: Members of the California Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development (GoBiz) and the Regional Economic Action Coalition (REACH) toured key infrastructure sites at Vandenberg Space Force Base Sept. 12, 2025, following the announcement of a "Space Vandenberg" initiative. At the announcement event, GoBiz, awarded REACH a $9.5 million grant to bolster California's space industry infrastructure and expand workforce development opportunities.
item.source:markdown:
Members of the California Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development (GoBiz) and the Regional Economic Action Coalition (REACH) toured key infrastructure sites at Vandenberg Space Force Base Sept. 12, 2025, following the announcement of a "Space Vandenberg" initiative. At the announcement event, GoBiz, awarded REACH a $9.5 million grant to bolster California's space industry infrastructure and expand workforce development opportunities.
![U.S. Space Force Lt. Col. Kyle Rowland, Chief of Spaceport Integration, speaks to members of the Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development (GoBiz) and Regional Economic Action Coalition (REACH) about infrastructure improvements at the Vandenberg harbor at Vandenberg Space Force base, Calif., Sept. 12, 2025. GoBiz recently awarded a $9.5 million grant to the "Space Vandenberg" initiative, aimed at boosting space industry infrastructure in California and expanding workforce development.](https://media.defense.gov/2025/Sep/23/2003807350/300/300/0/250912-X-EI987-1005.JPG)

item.title: Chumash Charity Golf Classic Beneficiaries Announced
item.description: SANTA YNEZ, CA – The Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians has announced that its upcoming 2025 Chumash Charity Golf Classic will raise funds for three local beneficiaries whose programs are making a difference in Santa Barbara County. Proceeds from the three-day golf tournament, which will be held September 23-25 at the Alisal Golf Course in Solvang, will go to Angels Foster Care, Child Abuse Listening Mediation (CALM) and Mental Wellness Center.
item.source:markdown: SANTA YNEZ, CA – The Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians has announced that its upcoming 2025 Chumash Charity Golf Classic will raise funds for three local beneficiaries whose programs are making a difference in Santa Barbara County. Proceeds from the three-day golf tournament, which will be held September 23-25 at the Alisal Golf Course in Solvang, will go to Angels Foster Care, Child Abuse Listening Mediation (CALM) and Mental Wellness Center.

item.title: Video: What Makes a Train Station Busy?
item.description: L.A. Metro's Regional Connector project opened in 2023 with three new stations. Despite its high profile, only one of those stations seems consistently busy. In this video, John compares them to understand why, and makes a lot of silly jokes along the way.
item.source:markdown: L.A. Metro's Regional Connector project opened in 2023 with three new stations. Despite its high profile, only one of those stations seems consistently busy. In this video, John compares them to understand why, and makes a lot of silly jokes along the way.

Over-the-Counter Sales of Overdose Reversal Medication Naloxone Decline After Initial Surge
item.description: Sales of the overdose reversal medication naloxone increased after it was made available to the public without a prescription but then dipped quickly in the period following debut of over-the-counter sales.
item.source:markdown: Sales of the overdose reversal medication naloxone increased after it was made available to the public without a prescription but then dipped quickly in the period following debut of over-the-counter sales.

item.title: Improving School Safety: What the Evidence Says
item.description: What are the biggest safety issues facing schools today? What might help schools respond to social media threats more effectively? Do teachers feel secure in their classrooms? RAND experts Pauline Moore and Brian Jackson tackle these questions and more, sharing practical insights from their research on creating safer school environments.
item.source:markdown: What are the biggest safety issues facing schools today? What might help schools respond to social media threats more effectively? Do teachers feel secure in their classrooms? RAND experts Pauline Moore and Brian Jackson tackle these questions and more, sharing practical insights from their research on creating safer school environments.

item.title: Natalie Crawford, Longtime RAND Analyst Who Guided Research on Modernizing Air Force, Dies at 86
item.description: Natalie Crawford, a RAND Corporation analyst and leading authority on U.S. air and space power who worked closely with top Air Force leaders to shape a research agenda focused on the effectiveness and modernization of the service, has died. She was 86 and had worked at RAND for more than 60 years before retiring earlier this year.
item.source:markdown: Natalie Crawford, a RAND Corporation analyst and leading authority on U.S. air and space power who worked closely with top Air Force leaders to shape a research agenda focused on the effectiveness and modernization of the service, has died. She was 86 and had worked at RAND for more than 60 years before retiring earlier this year.
